main event: On 1 November 1948, a radar sighting of an unidentified flying object was reported at Goose Bay Labrador, with the object traveling directly into the wind and disappearing after 10 minutes at a speed of approximately 60 mph.
interesting points: The object was too small at 7-1/2 miles to be an aircraft and too large to be a bird.
The blip traveled 4 miles in 4 minutes and 7 seconds, timed with a stop watch, indicating a speed of approximately 60 mph.
No apparent sound, trail, or weather effect was observed, and the object did not make any maneuvers.
The incident was reported as having no astronomical explanation, and it was suggested that the object could have been a balloon radiosonde.
The report also highlights discrepancies in the plotted path of the object
witnesses: M/Sgt Francis H. Mills, GCA Operator, and another CAA Operator
